replies.bodyText:
I tend to agree with Geoffrey. In the context of a constraint provider unit test, I'd like to focus on testing purely the constraint behavior, that is:

whether it's a penalty of a reward,
how many times it triggers (typically to verify number of matching unique pairs in the given set of objects),
whether the matchWeigher calculates the expected match weight (in cases it is affected by matching object properties, e.g. distance).

I would argue that @ConstraintWeight affects total score but not constraint behavior. So, if constraint weight configuration changes, constraints' behavior doesn't change, therefore the constraint provider unit test shouldn't fail.
In other words, I'd like to freely change my constraint weight configuration without breaking CP tests.

timeline.bodyText:
ConstraintStreamScoreDirectorFactory.getConstraints is non-public API.
We avoid defensive copies in non-public API, unless it's a probably-one-day-public-API, to avoid performance surprises and to reduce the code size. Note that even though the array is defensively copied, the constraint instances are not. So it's not watertight.
This method will never be part of a public API I'd argue.

This one is serious: if there an XStreamException or an IOException during read(InputStream), the error message won't mention the inputSolutionFile, which is important as a breadcrumb (to figure out what 's wrong for the user).
Why? that read(InputStream) throws an IllegalSargumentException and that isn't caught.
xstream exceptions are very common btw. Either invalid xml or  that has a  (there is no XSD).
Thinking further:
if there is such an xml parsing or element nesting error for an resource (not file), then we still want the resource name.
Suggestion to fix all of this:

Don't add read(InputStream(). Add readResource(String resource) instead. That also decreases the boilerplate in the NQueensCosntraintProviderTest
